description: Identity insertion is a noise scaling technique that amplifies errors by inserting identity operations (or identity-equivalent gate sequences) into the circuit, extending the circuit duration and exposing qubits to more decoherence.
Unlike unitary folding which applies G → GG†G transformations, identity insertion focuses on passive decoherence by inserting idle time or identity gates between computational operations.
This method is particularly effective when noise is dominated by idle qubit errors and T1/T2 decoherence rather than gate errors.
how_it_works: Identify locations in the circuit where identity operations can be inserted (typically between existing gates or layers).
Insert identity gates or identity layers to extend the circuit duration.
The scale factor is determined by the ratio of the extended circuit depth to the original depth.
Execute circuits with varying amounts of identity insertion and extrapolate to the zero-insertion limit.

key_equations.label: Basic transformation
key_equations.latex: G \mapsto I \cdot G \quad \text{or} \quad G \mapsto G \cdot I

advantages: Effective for noise models dominated by idle qubit decoherence
Does not require applying inverse gates (which may have different noise profiles)
disadvantages: Primarily scales idle/decoherence noise, not gate noise
Less effective when gate errors dominate over decoherence
Coarse control over the scale factor
May not accurately amplify correlated or non-Markovian noise
use_cases: ZNE when decoherence (T1, T2) dominates over gate errors
Circuits with significant idle time between operations
Situations where gate folding produces non-linear noise scaling
